statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description:
Even after a horrid shooting performance, Ray
Allen and Sam Cassell weren't about to stop taking shots.

related.description:
Milwaukee Bucks coach George Karl will miss Thursday night's game against the Toronto Raptors because of the
death of his father.
related.linkText: Bucks' Karl misses game after death of his father
related.title: Karl leaves Bucks after death of father
related.headline: Karl leaves Bucks after death of father

article.headline: Bucks topple Toronto to end five-game skid

images.name: Cassell, Sam 011206 inline
images.caption: Sam Cassell, right, found the ball on this play and his shooting touch as well, and there wasn't much Vince Carter and the Raptors could do about it.

article.linkText: Allen, Cassell find their shots as Bucks win
article.story:
MILWAUKEE (AP) -- Even after a horrid shooting performance, Ray Allen and Sam Cassell weren't about to stop taking shots. Allen and Cassell combined for 53 points Thursday night and helped the Milwaukee Bucks snap a five-game losing streak with a 95-89 victory over the Toronto Raptors. Allen and Cassell, who shot a combined 8-for-36 in a defeat against New York on Tuesday night, improved against Toronto. Allen scored 30 points on 12-for-22 shooting, while Cassell shot 11-for-16 and scored 23 points. "That was the worst shooting I've ever experienced in my career but, hey, I'm a shooter and my team relies on me," Allen said. "There's going to be nights like that." Cassell also shrugged off his poor shooting game. "I don't worry when I miss shots," Cassell said. "There's always tomorrow." Glenn Robinson and Tim Thomas each scored 13 for the Bucks, who were without coach George Karl. Karl missed the game because of the death of his father. Joseph Karl died in Marysville, Wash., Thursday morning. He was 95. It is the first time Karl has missed a game with the Bucks in his more than three years as coach. Assistant coach Terry Stotts led the Bucks in Karl's absence. "I think everybody in the locker room was thinking about George tonight," Stotts said. "I hope this can give him a little to smile about tonight." Vince Carter scored 26 points, Keon Clark 18 and Alvin Williams 16 for the Raptors. The Bucks scored the first seven points of the third quarter to push their lead to 53-39. The Raptors closed to seven points midway through the period before Milwaukee used an 11-0 run to put the game out of reach. Thomas scored on a drive and then hit back-to-back 3-pointers to give the Bucks a 72-54 lead with 2:59 left in the third. The Raptors cut into an 11-point deficit with a 9-4 run. Keon Clark scored six consecutive points and Carter added a 3-pointer to make it 85-78 with 5:20 left. The Raptors scored seven consecutive points to close to 89-85 with 2:57 left. Carter hit a layup and was fouled, but missed his free throw. "We made a heck of an effort to cut it down and we didn't quite get over the hump," Carter said. "It's not the last couple of minutes we're worried about, it's the beginning of the game." Milwaukee hit six free throws in the final two minutes and went 9-for-9 from the line in the fourth quarter. Toronto coach Lenny Wilkens was proud of the Raptors' comeback bid, but was upset about a no-call on a late drive by Carter. "We made a great run," Wilkens said. "Down the stretch, there were a couple of questionable calls. I thought Vince was grabbed and held and everybody in the arena saw it ... it wasn't called." Cassell and Allen combined for 30 points on 14-for-29 shooting as Milwaukee built a 46-39 lead by halftime. "They made great shots," Wilkens said. "They came off screens real well and we gave them too many good looks. If you give them good looks, they'll make them because they're great players. But we didn't play the type of defense we should have in the first half." The Bucks' losing streak hit five after falling 85-71 to the Knicks on Thursday. That game followed four consecutive defeats on a West Coast trip last week after a 9-1 start. "This team always seems to respond well to adversity and that showed tonight," Stotts said. Toronto center Hakeem Olajuwon scored nine points, moving past Dominique Wilkins into eighth place on the NBA's career scoring list with 26,673 points. Game notes
Forward Antonio Davis sat out with a swollen left knee. He is listed as day-to-day. Keon Clark started in place of Davis. ... Milwaukee forward Jason Caffey sat out the second half after straining his left hip in the second quarter. ... The Bucks have won 16 of their last 22 games against Toronto. ... Both teams were coming off nightmarish offensive performances, the Bucks losing 85-71 to the Knicks and the Raptors falling 85-69 to Boston.
